awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Plasmonically-Induced Phase-Correlated Ultralong Transport of Excitation Energy in Viral Quantum Dot Circuits
awd_abstract_narration:
An inspiring feature of certain photosynthetic organisms is their ability to transfer energy from one protein to another with significant efficiency and range. It has been shown that such a remarkable light harvesting process is deeply rooted in quantum mechanical processes at physiological temperatures. Imitating such processes to generate efficient and ultra-long range of flow of energy along specific paths in systems consisting of biologically assembled nanostructures is a transformative frontier of research with many technological impacts. This requires uncharted capabilities to control the energy transfer routes in real space with very low amount of loss. This project is a collaborative interdisciplinary effort between research groups with expertise in nanophotonics at the University of Alabama in Huntsville and virus nanotechnology at the University of Oklahoma. The team will develop transformative concepts and physical/biological processes that allow transfer of excitation energy in viral energy circuits over ultra-long distances that are relevant to nanodevices and their integration. The biologically-inspired energy circuits will consist of a nanowire, formed via a genetically modifiable protein landscape (phage) and semiconductor nanocrystals, and two designated nanocrystals that act as light harvesting and receiver antennas. The team will develop a novel material platform that can dramatically change the normal properties of such nanocrystals, allowing the viral nanowires to transport energy over long distances by closely imitating photosynthesis process. This includes energy transfer between domains of nanocrystals correlated with each other via their interaction with metallic nanostructures. This project offers a new path towards application of biology for building devices with nanoscale dimension. It will also create new opportunities for the design of efficient bio-inorganic hybrid systems for light emitting devices, detectors, and sensors. This interdisciplinary project will integrate physical and biological education by implementing a strong teaching and mentoring component, and will introduce the essence of nanotechnology and nanoscience to high school students.       
Technical 
The overall goal of this project is to develop transformative concepts and physical/biological processes for energy-transporting materials that will involve bio-inorganic composite structures and biologically-inspired collective properties. These processes allow transfer of excitation energy in viral energy circuits over ultra-long distances that are relevant to nanodevices and their integration (100 nm or more). Quantum dot nanowires formed via genetically engineered non-toxic virus will be used as energy channels. These quantum dot-coated viral nanowires will be biologically conjugated to a light harvesting antenna (Up-Conversion Nanoparticles) in one end and quantum dot receivers at the other end, forming biologically-templated energy circuits. The team will develop a novel landscape of material structure called metal oxide plasmonic metasubstrate (MOPM) to generate the transformative processes needed to allow the light energy absorbed by the light harvesting nanoantennas to be transported to the QD receivers along QD nanowires with low energy loss. MOPMs will be formed via the creative composition of metallic nanoantenna arrays, dielectric materials, and metal oxides. Immobilizing the biologically-templated energy circuits to MOPM leads to (i) formation of domains of phase-correlated dipole-dipole coupling between QDs across the viral nanowires, (ii) ultrahigh enhancement of their radiative decay (Purcell effect), and (iii) suppression of their defect environments. The transport of the energy across viral QD nanowires occurs via the transfer of excitation energy between the phase-correlated domains, rather than between individual QDs, and formation of inter-domain coupling using surface lattice resonances or plasmonic coupling. MOPM enhances QD-induced exciton-plasmon coupling significantly, aligning the dipoles of QDs in each domain while suppressing transfer of their energies to the metallic nanoantennas. These lead to ultralong range inter-domain energy transfer before radiative or non-radiative losses kick in.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Extensive research has devoted into comprehending the role of quantum effects in the energy transfer processes within light-harvesting complexes, including chlorophyll molecules. A distinctive aspect of this process is the spatial expansion of quantum states well beyond the dimensions of individual atoms. This award specifically concentrated on replicating certain facets of such processes in inorganic materials, investigating methods and concepts for efficient transport energy and quantum properties across substantial distances.

Intellectual Merit:

1-     A one of the aspects of achieving the goals of this award involved the development of complex optical systems capable of revealing unique features of energy transport in nanocrystal (quantum dots) assemblies. During the time of this award, sophisticated computerized integrated systems were devised and implemented to spectrally trace and image the energy transport in semiconductor nanocrystal assemblies at various physical depths. This not only enables a layer-by-layer depiction of energy transport in nanoparticle heterostructures but also reveals the impact of radiative and non-radiative decay of quantum emitters and their photo-activated processes on how they can transport excitation energy.

2-     In traditional nanoparticle systems, energy transport relies on the hopping of excitation energy from one nanoparticle to another, resulting in short-range and inefficient transport processes. This limitation hinders creative approaches for circuitry where excitation energy, rather than electrons or photons, is the primary conveyer. The outcomes of this award showed application of regions containing closely packed dipoles as carriers for excitation energy transport and coherent information. This was achieved by densely packing ultrasmall metallic nanoparticles in regions that were repeated laterally multiple times. Under specific conditions, these dipoles become coupled, forming resonances that spatially extend over the entire regions of the nanoparticles. This breakthrough opens the door to ultrafast transport of excitation energy and coherent properties.

 

3-     Acquiring knowledge about the physical properties of quantum/coherent systems is imperative, often entailing perturbations that inevitably alter the inherent nature of these systems. The outcomes of this award provides innovative avenues for utilizing far-field scattering as a tool to glean insights into complex coherent processes. The intricate details span establishment of networks comprising arrays of gold nanoparticles that are coupled together via phase properties of light. Such networks can carry phase information over long distances. Additionally, the study explores the manipulation of such a coupling process through the polarization of incident light, strategically aligning their phase properties to achieve distinctive light properties. This includes formation un-polarized light scattering observable at far distances at certain wavelength.

 

4-     Advancing the frontiers of information transport through the synergy of quantum mechanics and light-phase properties has the potential for profound technological impact. This awarded research broadens the scope of coherent transport by introducing the prospect of transmitting both energy and information. It achieves this by transferring time-dependent quantum properties from one atomically thin layer of semiconductor to another. As a result, the capacity for transferring quantum information between two locations is substantially increased, opening avenues for more efficient quantum encryption of information and the transport of energy.

 

5-     The transport of energy between semiconductor nanocrystals encounters limitations due to their inherent energies and lifetimes. Addressing these challenges, energy transport based on quantum processes presents an exceptionally rapid method for transferring energy across dissimilar types of nanocrystals. The results of this award highlight the effectiveness of using metallic nanoparticle arrays to facilitate energy transfer from nanocrystals emitting in visible wavelengths to those emitting in the infrared spectrum. This achievement led to the establishment of an energy circuit capable of efficiently transporting energy from a sender to a receiver through meticulously regulated phase processes in ultrafast fashion. The implications of such a process extend to devices with nanoscale dimensions, supporting the flow of energy in the form of excitation rather than conventional electrons or photons.

 

Broader Impacts:

The outcomes of this award are particularly significant in the realms of quantum information, quantum encryption, and the development of sensors utilizing phase-related processes for detection of biological molecules. Energy circuits supporting the flow of excitation energy present the possibility of novel, ultrafast, and compact devices. The results highlight the utilization of chiral features, typically obscured by conventional measurement methods, through precise control over the shape and sizes of metallic structures with nanoscale dimensions. This unveils significantly chiral features in the far field scattering by such structures, paving the way for biological sensors capable of detecting the structure of biomolecules. Furthermore, the outcomes demonstrate the creation nanoscale optical devices, such as light splitters with an effective thickness of about 40 nm, significantly less than a typical beam splitter. This finding may hold implications for photon entanglement. This award created good opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students at the University of Alabama in Huntsville, offering them technical and scientific training. The outcomes of undergraduate student research were shared with high school students via online presentations.
